slides.title: Welcome to the Noor Community Mentoring Program
slides.subtitle: Building a supportive future, together.

image.alt: Diverse team collaborating in a bright, modern office

slides.title: Benefits of Mentoring (Soft Skills)

image.alt: A group of people collaborating and brainstorming around a table

body: Mentoring is a powerful tool for personal and professional growth. It can help you develop a wide range of soft skills that support success in any field.
list: Improved communication and interpersonal skills
Enhanced leadership and decision-making abilities
Increased confidence and self-awareness
Greater problem-solving and critical thinking skills

slides.title: Who Are We?

image.alt: A diverse group of colleagues celebrating a success together

body: The Noor Community is an educational space dedicated to liberation through learning. We believe in solidarity and social justice.

Our goal is to create a safe environment where everyone can express themselves, develop their skills, and connect with others. We see learning and teaching as universal processes that empower all of us.

slides.title: What Is Mentoring?

image.alt: A mentor guiding a mentee at a computer

body: Mentoring is a collaborative relationship where an experienced person supports another learner to develop skills and reach their goals.
Our approach centres trust and empowerment. Mentors act as guides who celebrate wins, ask thoughtful questions, and help you stay accountable to your project vision.

slides.title: What Becomes Possible?
slides.subtitle: Mentoring can help you achieve concrete, practical outcomes.

questions.prompt: What is the Noor Community primarily committed to?

options.label: Building solidarity and working toward social justice through education.
Organising competitive events that reward the top performers only.
Delivering self-paced online courses without community interaction.

questions.correctFeedback: Exactly! Our community centres solidarity and social justice.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Review our vision—connection and justice are at the heart of Noor Community.

questions.prompt: How does the mentoring relationship operate in this program?

options.label: The mentor gives orders and the mentee follows a fixed set of tasks.
Mentor and mentee collaborate to reach the mentee’s goals through trust and guidance.
The mentor grades the mentee each week on quizzes and exams.

questions.correctFeedback: Yes! Mentoring here is a collaborative, empowering partnership.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Remember—the mentor is a guide who supports, not a judge or taskmaster.

slides.title: Project Story: Developing a CV
slides.quote: "I needed a strong CV to apply for work."

image.alt: A person writing a CV at a desk

process.label: The Process:
process.text: Laila partnered with her mentor to identify key skills, choose powerful action verbs, and organise her experience into a compelling narrative.

outcome.label: The Outcome:
outcome.text: She now has a polished CV that highlights her strengths and feels confident applying for new opportunities.

image.alt: A person giving a presentation to an audience

process.label: The Process:
process.text: Mariam practised weekly with her mentor, using recordings to reflect on pacing, body language, and clarity.

outcome.label: The Outcome:
outcome.text: She delivered a confident presentation and built a repeatable routine for future talks.

slides.title: Create a Measurable Project

image.alt: A group of people working together to achieve a goal

body: Successful projects require clear goals. To make sure your project is effective, we use the SMART framework.
This approach keeps outcomes measurable and realistic for a three-month partnership.

slides.title: Example: A SMART Goal

image.alt: A person writing in a notebook

body: Consider the broad goal: "I want to improve my CV."
To make it SMART, add clear actions and a deadline: "I will update my CV to describe three key skills with evidence and finish by the end of this month."

slides.title: Project Journey Milestones
slides.subtitle: Refine your idea, match with a mentor, and plan together.

image.alt: A person interacting with an AI assistant

body: Each mentoring partnership moves through three steady stages.

steps.title: Step 1: AI Guide
steps.description: Use our planning tool to turn your idea into a detailed SMART proposal.

steps.title: Step 2: Mentor Matching
steps.description: We review your project and pair you with someone whose expertise aligns with your goals.

steps.title: Step 3: First Meeting
steps.description: You and your mentor set expectations and map out weekly tasks for the coming months.

questions.prompt: What happens right after you submit your project proposal?

options.label: The team reviews it and pairs you with a mentor whose experience fits your goal.
You immediately present your project to the whole community.
You complete reimbursement paperwork for supplies.

questions.correctFeedback: Correct—the team reviews your plan and matches you with the right mentor.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Not quite. Review the journey slides to see what happens post-submission.

questions.prompt: What is the focus of the first mentor meeting?

options.label: Co-creating detailed weekly steps and agreeing on expectations.
Celebrating the final results of your project.
Submitting monthly reports to the admin team.

questions.correctFeedback: Exactly! The first meeting sets the shared weekly plan.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Check the milestone slide—the first session is about planning, not reporting yet.

image.alt: A person working at a desk with a clock in the background

list.text: The project is designed to be completed in three months.
Mentors allocate up to one hour each week for check-ins and feedback.
If needed, you can request a one-month extension to complete final pieces.

questions.prompt: How long is each weekly mentoring session designed to last?

options.label: About 30 minutes focused on reflection and planning.
Exactly 60 minutes with required presentations.
No set time—mentees drop in and out at any point.

questions.correctFeedback: Great! Weekly check-ins are focused, 30-minute conversations.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Take another look—the program keeps meetings short and consistent.

questions.prompt: What happens if a mentee misses three sessions in a row without an acceptable reason?

options.label: They receive extra time with their mentor to catch up.
The project is placed on hold until the mentee is ready to re-engage.
They are automatically assigned a new mentor.

questions.correctFeedback: Correct—the project pauses so mentees can return when ready.
questions.incorrectFeedback: Review the boundaries slide; consistency keeps the partnership active.

slides.subtitle: Let’s surface your ideas and questions.

image.alt: A group of people brainstorming with sticky notes

body: Take a moment to share any project ideas already on your mind.
We’ll spend the next 20 minutes using the AI guide tool to draft initial proposals.
Bring forward any questions about the mentoring process or your concept.

questions.prompt: Which sentence uses sensory detail most effectively?

slides.title: The Writing Process
slides.subtitle: Arrange the stages from first to last.

image.alt: Writer planning ideas with a notebook and laptop

slides.instructions: Move the stages until they are in the correct order, then check your work.

items.label: Prewriting
items.explanation: Prewriting is the first step, where you brainstorm ideas, research, and outline your topic before you begin writing.

items.label: Drafting
items.explanation: Drafting is the second stage. This is where you write the first version of your text, focusing on getting your ideas down on paper.

items.label: Revising
items.explanation: Revising is the third stage. Here, you review the content, organization, and clarity of your draft, making significant changes to improve the overall piece.

items.label: Editing & Proofreading
items.explanation: Editing & Proofreading is the fourth stage. After revising the big picture, you focus on correcting grammar, spelling, punctuation, and formatting errors.

items.label: Publishing
items.explanation: Publishing is the final stage, where you share your polished work with its intended audience.

slides.title: Discourse Markers
slides.subtitle: Categorise these linking words by their function.

image.alt: Stacks of books on a library table

slides.instructions: Assign each linking word to the function it best represents.

items.label: However
items.explanation: 'However' is used to introduce a statement that contrasts with or seems to contradict something that has been said previously.

items.label: Furthermore
items.explanation: 'Furthermore' adds another piece of information to the point you are making.

items.label: Therefore
items.explanation: 'Therefore' indicates that a statement is the logical consequence of the one that came before it.

items.label: On the other hand
items.explanation: 'On the other hand' is used to present a contrasting point of view.

items.label: As a result
items.explanation: 'As a result' shows that the second statement is a result of the first.

items.label: Moreover
items.explanation: 'Moreover' is used to introduce a piece of information that adds to or supports the previous one.

slides.title: States of Matter
slides.subtitle: Match each state to its defining properties.

image.alt: Scientist working with a glowing plasma ball

slides.instructions: For each state of matter, choose the property that best fits before checking your answers.

rows.label: Solid
rows.explanation: A solid's particles are tightly packed in a fixed structure, giving it a definite shape and volume.

rows.label: Liquid
rows.explanation: A liquid's particles can slide past one another, allowing it to take the shape of its container, but its volume remains constant.

rows.label: Gas
rows.explanation: A gas's particles are far apart and move randomly, allowing it to expand to fill any container, giving it an indefinite shape and volume.

rows.label: Plasma
rows.explanation: Plasma is a superheated state of matter where atoms are stripped of their electrons, creating an ionized gas.
